summary_md: Last round replaced the invalid leaf‑forcing with two robust forcing methods and consolidated typicality conclusions across natural local metrics. Main technical tools: (i) sealed‑bubble forcing — attach a finite D‑saturated block H by a single edge so H has no spare stubs; that edge is then a bridge in every admissible extension (works for =D when D is odd and for ≤D if implemented with care); (ii) interior pendant‑subtree forcing — place a finite pendant path/subtree strictly inside a larger ball so the attaching edge is a bridge in all completions (works in G_{•,≤D} for all D≥2). Parity blocks sealed one‑edge cuts when D is even, but we prove 2‑way infinite bridges are dense yet meagre for D>2; hence in =D with even D bridgeless graphs are comeagre. Under any strongly‑local / cylinder‑open (Polish/Baire) topology (including d_• and typical weighted/FO‑local variants) these forcing arguments imply: bridgeless is nowhere dense in G_{•,≤D} (all D) and in G_{•,=D} for odd D, while bridgeless is comeagre in =D for even D. Remaining work: formalize boundary data/base and D‑regular completion lemmas, and investigate genuine nonlocal Baire metrics that could flip typicality.
one_line_summary: Sealed‑bubble and pendant‑subtree forcing: bridgeless nowhere dense (odd D); even‑D regular comeagre
highlights: Sealed‑bubble forcing: build a finite D‑saturated block H attached by one edge; H has no spare stubs so the connecting edge is a bridge in every extension (valid for odd D regular).
Interior pendant‑subtree forcing: place a finite pendant path/subtree strictly inside a larger ball so its attachment edge is a forced bridge in all completions — works in G_{•,≤D} for every D≥2.
Parity obstruction: when D is even a sealed one‑edge finite cut is impossible (cut size parity), so the sealed‑bubble method fails; nevertheless 2‑way bridges are dense but meagre for D>2.
Category conclusions (strongly‑local / cylinder‑open metrics): bridgeless is nowhere dense in G_{•,≤D} (all D) and in G_{•,=D} for odd D; bridgeless is comeagre in =D when D is even.
Nonlocal metrics can trivially change openness (e.g. add a global “has a bridge” bit); any meaningful alternate metric must be shown metrizable/Baire and have different cylinder‑density behavior.
next_questions: Formalize the boundary datum Π and prove the tame / cylinder‑open topology is Polish (countable base A(F,Π), Baire property).
Construct an explicit odd‑D D‑regular sealed‑bubble gadget and prove an infinite D‑regular completion lemma realizing the refined ball.
Decide bridgeless typicality in G_{•,≤D} for even D under cylinder‑based methods or find a natural nonlocal Baire metric that (provably) makes bridgeless typical.
